channel.title: Don't use # to indicate root or $ to indicate user in documentation
channel.description:
As per... - https://www.whonix.org/forum/index.php/topic,1354.msg8774.html#msg8774 - http://i.imgur.com/GRxPu0n.png
Where a user has run literally.
[code]# ln -s /etc/apparmor.d/libvirt/TEMPLATE.qemu /etc/apparmor.d/libvirt/TEMPLATE.kvm[/code]
I.e. including the [font=arial]#[/font]. Therefore perfectly making my point.
I know, there is somewhat a convention in linux documentation. [font=arial]#[/font] means, run as root [font=arial]$[/font] means, run as user
In Whonix documentation, I've broken that convention. It confuses users. Only geeks know that. Not people who get to learn Linux.
I suggest to use [font=arial]sudo[/font] instead of [font=arial]#[/font]. And for commands that should be run as user, we just note above, that it should be run as user, not root.
